title: Teaching
text:
Over the past two decades at RPI, I’ve taught an unusually broad range of topics—database design, quantitative methods, internet marketing, entrepreneurship, applied machine learning, and applied projects. My teaching philosophy adapts to the type of course, but the central theme remains constant: fundamental shifts in the economics of data creation, storage, and use are transforming individuals, organizations, and markets.




MGMT6841


Practicum in Management (MBA Project Course)


Applied project course where MBA students work on real data science and analytics challenges with industry partners. Students develop compelling professional narratives through hands-on problem-solving.




MGMT6445 / MGMT6790


Business Analytics Capstone


Capstone experience for MS Business Analytics students, partnering with companies to address complex, data-driven problems. Each semester features 4-8 projects from a diverse mix of established firms and startups.




MGMT4530/6630


Starting a New Venture


Entrepreneurship course covering opportunity identification, customer discovery, business model development, and go-to-market strategy for technology-based ventures.




ITWS4500


Agentic AI and Web Systems Development (Spring 2026)


New course introducing students to cutting-edge approaches in cloud deployment and agentic AI development, ensuring ITWS coursework remains current with modern techniques.







MGMT4190/6560


Introduction to Machine Learning Applications


Developed core course taking students from Python basics through deep learning applications. Now taught by multiple instructors across Business Analytics, Supply Chain, and Finance programs. Course materials available at introml.analyticsdojo.com.




ITWS


Quantum-Inspired Optimization (Fall 2025)


One-credit pilot course developed in collaboration with BQP, engaging students in exploring quantum-inspired optimization. Materials at quantum.analyticsdojo.com.

title: Projects
text:
ChatMFG addresses a critical gap in AI adoption for manufacturers who recognize the transformative potential of large language models but cannot adopt cloud-based solutions due to data security and intellectual property concerns.
The platform enables manufacturers to deploy advanced LLM capabilities entirely within their own secure environments, featuring manufacturing-optimized models, retrieval-augmented generation (RAG) for proprietary documents, and human-in-the-loop fine-tuning.
Developed in collaboration with RPI’s Center for Smart Convergent Manufacturing Systems (CSCMS) and industry partner Sono-Tek Corporation.




Startup Tech Valley is a regional initiative fostering the entrepreneurship and innovation ecosystem in New York’s Tech Valley region. The program connects startups with resources, mentors, investors, and economic development organizations to accelerate growth and commercialization.




Through my teaching and research, I maintain active collaborations with companies across multiple sectors:
Analytics & AI – Enterprise Partners: Amazon, Credit Suisse, Invesco, GlobalFoundries, Johnson & Johnson, CDPHP
Startups – Emerging Technology: Velan Studios, ACV Auctions, P1ston, BQP, Mind Genomics, Defacto Global
Research Centers – Academic Partnerships: Center for Smart Convergent Manufacturing Systems (CSCMS), NYS Center of Excellence in Data Science
These partnerships generate unique datasets, theoretically significant research questions, and meaningful student experiences through capstone projects and applied research.






Founded and served as CEO of getOUT4, a technology startup focused on social coordination and local event discovery. The experience informed my research on entrepreneurship ecosystems and my approach to teaching entrepreneurship.



Open-source educational platform providing Jupyter-based learning materials for analytics and data science. Materials are used in multiple courses and have been adopted by other institutions.

quantum.analyticsdojo.com – Quantum optimization materials

Managed RPI’s Change the World Challenge business plan competition
Built partnerships with regional accelerators, investors, and economic development organizations

This practical engagement continues through my role in the NSF I-Corps Program and the NY State Incubator Grant.

title: About
text:
Jason Kuruzovich is an Associate Professor of Business Analytics at the Lally School of Management at Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute (RPI), where his research explores the intersection of information systems, computer science, and the practical challenges businesses face in a data-driven world. His work examines how individuals and organizations derive value from information systems, artificial intelligence (AI), and digital transformation, with a particular emphasis on the societal and organizational implications of algorithmic decision-making.
Professor Kuruzovich’s research has been published in leading journals across multiple disciplines, including Management Science, Information Systems Research, MIS Quarterly, the Journal of Marketing, and the Journal of Applied Psychology. His studies have addressed topics such as online platforms and digital marketplaces, algorithmic bias in AI-based decision systems, and the evolving dynamics of innovation and entrepreneurship ecosystems.



Recent work focuses on applied artificial intelligence and fairness in machine learning, including collaborations with technology and analytics firms. His coauthored paper, “Reducing Subgroup Differences in Personnel Selection Through the Application of Machine Learning,” received the 2025 Personnel Psychology Best Paper Award, the SIOP Jeanneret Award for Excellence in the Study of Individual or Group Assessment, and recognition as one of the ten most-cited papers in Personnel Psychology in 2023.
Another study, “Whither Bias Goes, I Will Go: An Integrative, Systematic Review of Algorithmic Bias Mitigation,” published in the Journal of Applied Psychology, offers a comprehensive framework for understanding algorithmic fairness across organizational and computational contexts.



His ongoing research in entrepreneurship and innovation builds on his decade-long leadership of the Severino Center for Technological Entrepreneurship, where he helped foster the startup ecosystem in New York’s Capital Region through programs such as Startup Tech Valley and RPI’s Change the World Challenge. This practical engagement continues through his role as Principal Investigator for the NSF I-Corps Program at RPI and the New York State Incubator Grant, initiatives that help early-stage entrepreneurs commercialize research-based innovations and bridge academic insight with startup success.



In teaching, Professor Kuruzovich emphasizes applied analytics and experiential learning. His courses—ranging from Introduction to Machine Learning Applications to the MBA Practicum in Management—integrate technical skills with strategic insight, guiding students through complex, data-driven problems faced by real companies. These courses provide students with hands-on experience addressing industry challenges through rigorous analysis and innovative solutions.
His pedagogical approach combines theory, computation, and storytelling to help students craft professional narratives grounded in applied success.



Over nearly two decades at RPI, Professor Kuruzovich has taught at the undergraduate, graduate, and executive levels, led multiple academic programs, and mentored numerous Ph.D. students who have gone on to successful academic and industry careers.
Current Administrative Roles:

Area Head, Information Technology and Web Science (July 2025 – Present)
Area Head, Information Systems, Operations, Supply Chain, Marketing, Business Economics, and Business Analytics, Lally School of Management (July 2024 – Present)
Principal Investigator, NSF I-Corps Program at RPI (February 2016 – Present)

Previous Leadership:

Director, Lally School Ph.D. Program (July 2022 – July 2023)
Director, Severino Center for Technological Entrepreneurship (July 2013 – July 2023)




Ph.D., Information Systems University of Maryland, Robert H. Smith School of Business, 2006
B.S., Chemical Engineering (Cum Laude) Lafayette College, 1996



Before entering academia, Professor Kuruzovich worked in industry as a chemical engineer, SAP implementation consultant, and business systems analyst at companies including Air Products and Chemicals, Johnson & Johnson, and Streamline.com. He also founded getOUT4 and served as a consulting data scientist with Defacto Global Inc. and Mind Genomics Inc.

title: Research
text:
My research explores how artificial intelligence and digital technologies are transforming organizations, markets, and society. I focus on data-intensive, applied research that integrates theory building with real-world impact through collaborations with industry partners.




I examine issues such as algorithmic bias, AI fairness, and human–AI collaboration in decision-making contexts. This stream of work includes collaborations with leading interviewing and selection platforms, exploring how machine learning models built on natural language and audio data can both encode and mitigate bias in organizational decision-making.
Key questions: How can organizations leverage AI responsibly? What are the mechanisms through which language-based AI models may inadvertently reproduce demographic and linguistic biases? How can we develop methodological innovations to reduce such bias?



I study how information systems and AI shape competition, transparency, and user behavior in online marketplaces. This body of work developed foundational insights into how information availability and search costs shape both buyer and seller behavior.
Key questions: How do online platforms alter market efficiency? How do sellers strategically exploit information asymmetries? How do platform transparency policies affect user contributions?



I investigate how digital tools and data enable entrepreneurial adaptation and ecosystem evolution. Building on my decade-long leadership of the Severino Center for Technological Entrepreneurship, I examine how entrepreneurs leverage digital tools to navigate uncertainty, pivot business models, and engage with innovation ecosystems.
Key questions: How do government grants shape entrepreneurial ecosystems? How can large language models help measure startup pivots? How does social media affect venture financing?
